EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  8.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Glenn Vander Zee, Assistant Superintendent of Educational Services, Kirsten King, Director of Assessment & Accountability, and Lucretia Peebles, Ph.D., Administrator for Charter School Oversight
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action of District Board Policy for Charter Renewal and Recommended Renewal Protocol
	 
This item is an overview of charter school renewal policy as delineated in the East Side Union High School District (ESUHSD) Board Policy 0420.42 (Attachment A) which emanates from Education Code §47607 (Attachment B). Renewals are “governed by the standards and criteria” (Education Code §47607(a) (2)) in Education Code 47605 (Attachment C). This item also provides a review of recommended (or optional) charter renewal protocol (Attachment D). 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive the District Board Policy for Charter Renewal and Recommended Renewal Protocol.

FROM:

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Receive Charter School Renewal Petition from Summit Public Schools: Rainier Charter School
	 
This item officially acknowledges that the Board of Trustees has received the Summit Public Schools charter renewal petition from Summit Public Schools: Rainier Charter School. The school, located on the Mt. Pleasant High School campus, opened fall 2011 and serves approximately 361 students, grades 9-12. The Summit Public Schools: Rainier charter petition was first approved on September 16, 2010, with a term of five years, beginning on July 1, 2011, and ending on June 30, 2016. The Board is required to hold a public hearing within thirty (30) days of receipt of a charter petition and render a decision within sixty (60) days.  The Board will hold a public hearing at the November 19, 2015, meeting to hear public comment on the charter petition. The petition will be evaluated by the district team and a recommendation will be presented to the Board at the meeting on December 10, 2015.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive the Charter School Renewal Petition for Summit Public Schools: Rainier submitted by Summit Public Schools.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  8.04
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion/Action to Review Relationship between San Jose Police Department Campus Security Services and Student Discipline Issues
	 
	 
In August, we received a Public Records Request from NBC Bay Area News Investigative Unit, along with other districts in the Bay Area, requesting information regarding the number of students referred to police and issued a police citation.  These records are sent to the US Department of Education Data Collection, Office of Civil Rights, every two years.  We provided the data to NBC and I was interviewed in early September. 
	 
The focus of the story was School-to-Prison Pipeline with the underlying premise being that having police officers on campus leads to an increase in police referrals, thus increasing the number of police citations that are issued.
	 
NBC focused on our District's data comparing 2011/2012 to 2013/14.  In 2011/12, there were 1,745 police referrals and 214 school-related arrests.  In 2013/14, there were 230 police referrals and 15 school-related arrests.
We need to peel the onion back further to understand the data and the types of offenses that occurred that lead to the police citation.  Although the trend data is going down in a positive direction and the District has implemented policy changes that should continue to improve the data, there is still much research to complete and a full discussion needs to take place.
	 
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board add this discussion item to the agenda of the November Board Study Session and that staff bring forward the data needed to have a full, transparent dialogue on police interaction with students and the number and type of citations that are issued by school and by ethnicity.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Receive Charter School Renewal Petition from Latino College Preparatory Academy Submitted by The Foundation for Hispanic Education
	 
	 
This item officially acknowledges that the Board of Trustees has received The Foundation for Hispanic Education charter renewal petition for Latino College Preparatory Academy. The school, currently located on the now closed National Hispanic University campus, serves approximately 420 students, grades 9-12. The Latino College Preparatory Academy charter petition was first approved on January 29, 2001, and has twice been renewed by the Board: April 6, 2006 and March 24, 2011. The Board is required to hold a public hearing within thirty (30) days of receipt of a charter petition and render a decision within sixty (60) days, unless both parties agreed to a 30-day extension. The Board will hold a public hearing at the November 19, 2015, meeting to hear public comment on the charter petition. The petition will be evaluated by the District team and a recommendation will be presented to the Board at the meeting on December 10, 2015.
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive the Charter School Renewal Petition for Latino College Preparatory Academy  submitted by The Foundation for Hispanic Education.

Item:  9.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cari Vaeth, Associate Superintendent of Human Resources
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:05 p.m. - Disclosure of Major Provisions of Proposed Tentative Agreement with East Side Teachers Association/CTA/NEA, August 31, 2015 - July 31, 2018 (Per AB1200; Government Code Section 3547.5); Discussion and/or Action
	 
	 
Government Code section 3547.5 requires school districts to disclose, at a public meeting, the major provisions of a proposed collective bargaining agreement including, but not limited to, the costs that would be incurred by the public school employer under the agreement for the current and subsequent fiscal years.  In meeting the requirement, a public hearing is being held to give our community an opportunity to comment on the cost of this tentative agreement. 
	Attached is a copy of the proposed changes to the collective bargaining agreement with the East Side Teachers Association/CTA/NEA.  The District and the East Side Teachers Association/CTA/NEA reached a tentative agreement on September 11, 2015.  The tentative agreement was ratified by the East Side Teachers Association membership on September 30, 2015.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
As presented 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept any comment on the proposed Tentative Agreement with the East Side Teachers Association/CTA/NEA, August 31, 2015 - July 31, 2018 (Per AB1200; Government Code Section 3547.5).

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Ratify and Approve Tentative Agreement with East Side Teachers Association/CTA/NEA, August 31, 2015 - July 31, 2018
	 
	 
Attached is a copy of the proposed changes to the collective bargaining agreement with the East Side Teachers Association/CTA/NEA.  The District and the East Side Teachers Association/CTA/NEA reached a tentative agreement on September 11, 2015.  The tentative agreement was ratified by the East Side Teachers Association membership on September 30, 2015.  We are submitting this agreement to the Board of Trustees for approval.
	 
In addition, Government Code section 3547.5 provides that before entering into a collective bargaining agreement the public school employer shall disclose the major provisions of the agreement, including, but not limited to, the costs that would be incurred by the public school employer under the agreement for the current and subsequent fiscal years.  In meeting that requirement, a public hearing was held to give our community an opportunity to comment on the cost of this tentative agreement.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
As per the attached disclosure 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Funds
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees ratify the tentative agreement between the East Side Union High School District and the East Side Teachers Association/CTA/NEA for the period August 31, 2015 - July 31, 2018.

SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:10 p.m. Regarding the Proposed Adoption of the Initial Proposal for Contract Reopeners for 2015-2016: From East Side Union High School District to the San Jose Federation of Teachers Local 957, AFT, AFL-CIO
	 
	 
 
The East Side Union High School District presents the following contract reopener proposal to the San Jose Federation of Teachers Local 957, AFT, AFL-CIO, for the 2015-2016 school year.  Pursuant to Government Code §3547, the District’s initial proposal must be presented to the public in open session at a public meeting.
	 
The District continues to acknowledge and appreciate the contributions made to its mission and programs by its adult education certificated employees, and continues to seek the utilization of equitable and collaborative methods of addressing the needs of the students, parents and employees of the East Side Union High School District.  Accordingly, the District initially proposes to continue the language of the present agreement for the 2015-2016 school year except as modified in a manner consistent with the matters and issues described below.
	 
The District proposes the following areas for negotiations: total compensation package which includes salary and benefits; and contract language amendments to Article 18000 – Performance Review.   
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be negotiated
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Various
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees sunshine and accept any comment on the District's initial proposal for contract reopeners to the San Jose Federation of Teachers Local 957, AFT, AFL-CIO for the 2015-2016 school year.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  11.02
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Randy Phelps, Chief Technology Officer
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action regarding Broadcasting of District Board Meetings
		 
		 
At the August 20, 2015, Board meeting, it was requested that staff begin investigating the efficacy and cost of broadcasting Board meetings either over the internet or possibly on cable television.  The District staff has completed the investigation and will report its findings and the particulars as it relates to timelines, costs and requirements.
		 
Both systems are viable. The costs do not include additional labor during broadcast events, the designs suggested would not require additional labor.  
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$50,000 Not to exceed installation and first year costs
$20,000 Not to exceed annual fees license, maintenance, etc. 
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Discretionary Fund
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees discuss the option to broadcast Board meetings and authorize administration to proceed as directed.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  12.02
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Glenn Vander Zee, Assistant Superintendent of Educational Services
						 
SUBJECT:
Receive the Third Quarterly Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaints Quarterly Report for Period covering July 1, 2015 through September 30, 2015
		 
BACKGROUND
As a result of the Williams Case (EC 35186), referred to as a landmark Superior Court case requires that every California public school provide each student with, at the very least, sufficient textbooks and instructional materials; clean, safe and functional buildings and facilities; and permanent, appropriately trained and assigned teachers.  Additionally, under the settlement of the Valenzuela/CAHSEE Settlement (EC 37254) students in grades 10 to 12 inclusive shall be notified of services available to students up to two consecutive years after the completion of grade 12 who have not yet passed the CAHSEE.
		 
School districts shall support summarized data on the nature and resolution of all Williams Complaints and Valenzuela/CAHSEE Complaints on a quarterly basis to the governing board and the county superintendent of schools.  The report shall include the number of complaints by general subject area with the number of resolved and unresolved complaints.
		 
The attached report indicates the number of complaints, if any, filed from July 1, 2015 through September 30, 2015.
		 
FISCAL IMPACT
None
		 
FUNDING SOURCE
Senate Bill 6 (Williams)
State Instructional Materials Allocation
District Instructional Materials Budget
Other Categorical funds as Appropriate
		 
RECOMMENDATIONS
The administration recommends that the Governing Board accept the Third Quarterly Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint Report for the period covering July 1, 2015 through September 30, 2015, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727).
items.item_recommendation: The Administration recommends that the Governing Board accept the Third Quarterly Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint Report for the period covering July 1, 2015 through September 30, 2015, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727).

SUBJECT:
Presentation and Discussion regarding the Electric Bus Project
	 
	 
The District has an opportunity to retro-fit existing school bus diesel engines with electric engines.  The Silicon Valley Clean Cities Coalition (SVCCC) in partnership with six other organizations will work together to provide financial and operational support for this endeavor.  The ultimate goal of SVCCC is to get diesel engines off the road.  The District will use school buses that are not currently in operable condition.  The electric engine will operate on solar power which will reduce operating cost. 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Not Applicable

SUBJECT:
Presentation and Discussion regarding the Child Nutrition Services Administrative Review 
		 
		 
The East Side Union High School District participates in the National School Lunch and Breakfast Programs.  These federally funded programs are required to be reviewed every three years.  There are five major categories reviewed; Meal Access and Reimbursements, Meal Patter and Nutritional Quality, Resource Management,m General Program Compliance and Summer Seamless Option.  After visiting three high schools, spending numerous hours reviewing records and completing a comprehensive review there were no findings to the Administrative Review

SUBJECT:
Presentation and Discussion regarding the Short-Term Non-Certificated Summer Staffing Initiative
		 
On May 14, 2015, the Board adopted Resolution #2014/2015-23 to hire short-term non-certificated summer staffing.  Over the summer, approximately 35 short-term employees were hired to support Facilities, Warehouse, Grounds, computer recycling, and updating fixed asset data. The work performed in these functional areas is not often regular and recurring with the exception of grounds and requires some additional staffing augmentation.  The summer work initiative used a combination of funding sources totaling $117,114.00.
		 
The work that was completed enhanced the aesthetic, cleanliness, safety, security and operational functionality of the school campuses.  Performing the work over the summer months provided ease of access to school site facilities.  Staff will present the results of this summer's staffing initiative.      
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
Not Applicable

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  13.05
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve First Amendment to Metropolitan Education District Joint Powers Agreement
	 
	 
Background: 
The six (6) member districts entered into an agreement in 1983 to establish a joint powers agency initially called the Central Santa Clara County Regional Occupational Agency, renamed Metropolitan Education District in 1997 which agreement was replaced in its entirety in 2001.  Students from charter schools and private schools have been allowed to attend and enroll in MetroED programs.  Prior to the Local Control Funding Formula (LCFF), revenue from the state provided the necessary funding for these students based on ADA.  As part of the LCFF implementation in 2012-13, ROP funds were redirected to the school districts and through the maintenance of effort requirements and the MetroED JPA Master Business Agreements, member districts have continued to pass-through funds to MetroED.  However, funds for charter school students and private school students are not included as part of this funding stream.  Consequently, these students have been participating in our programs for “free”. 
	 
	 
Current Considerations:
The MetroED JPA Agreement needs to be amended to allow MetroED to provide, on a fee-for-service and space-available basis, career technical education programs and services to additional third party participants that meet eligibility and legal criteria, in accordance with an executed Memorandum of Understanding and to make other conforming changes.  Additional participants include, but is not limited to, charter schools and private schools operating inside and outside the boundaries of the member districts.  Attached for Governing Board approval is the First Amendment to the Metropolitan Education District Joint Powers Agreement (JPA).  The First Amendment must also be approved by each member districts’ Governing Board. 
	 
The language of the First Amendment was reviewed by MetroED’s legal counsel.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be determined and discussed with member districts.
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the First Amendment to the Metropolitan Education District Joint Powers Agreement and to obtain subsequent approval from each member districts’ Board and to authorize the Superintendent to take any necessary actions.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  15.01
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and Farshid Samsami, Program Manager, SGI Construction Management, Inc.
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Presentation and/or Discussion regarding the Bond Program Update
		 
In 2002, voters in the East Side Union High School District approved Bond Measure G in the amount of $298 million for the purpose of modernizing existing school facilities and building new facilities to support the changing needs of education in the District. A substantial portfolio of projects has been completed under Measure G, which is concluding with a district-wide site improvement initiative, currently underway.
		 
In 2008, voters in the District approved Bond Measure E in the amount of $349 million for the purpose of continuing the modernization of existing school facilities and building new facilities.  With the exception of two projects currently in construction and near completion and one in the DSA for review and approval, all Measure E projects have been completed. Also, recently Board of Trustees just approved spending of their $48M discretionary funds to be used at various sites to pay for construction escalation, new project at WC Overfelt new Administration/Art Building and Yerba Buena Student Center.
		 
In 2012, voters in the District approved Bond Measure I in the amount of $120 million, allowing the school modernization program to expand its impact to support the changing needs of education in the District.  Some school sites have Measure E project savings, which supplements their Measure I allocations on their approved new projects. Most Measure I projects are either in programming or design phase, except 4 schools which architect and construction management teams are being selected.
		 
An update on the status of the District’s Bond Program is presented for discussion.

SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion, and/or Action to Allocate Funds for Alternative Education Facility Upgrades at Independence Adult Education Center, Independence, Oak Grove, W.C. Overfelt, and Yerba Buena High School
	 
On September 25, 2014 (Board Item 5.05), Administration presented a space plan for alternative education facilities Districtwide. Since that time, progress has been made on the various components in order to prepare instructional and administrative space for charter schools at Oak Grove, W.C. Overfelt and Independence High Schools, including development of temporary housing at Independence High School, and preparation of space for incoming charter schools at Oak Grove and W.C. Overfelt High Schools.  Components of the plan still in progress include preparation of space for Post Senior at Independence High School, new space for Pegasus High School, modernization of space for ACE and DCP charter schools, and a restroom building at Yerba Buena.  A presentation of the current status of those plans will be made to the Board of Trustees.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
26.1 million
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure E Board/Cabinet Contingency $19.6 million
Measure E Alternative Education allocation $80,942.21
Measure I Alternative Education allocation $2,126,408.34
Measure I (restoration of Measure E for Alternative Education) $1,546,227
Capital Facilities Fund 25 $2,746,422.45
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board allocate $26.1 million, funded as indicated above, to alternative education facility upgrades at Independence Adult Education Center, Independence, Oak Grove, W.C. Overfelt and Yerba Buena High Schools.

Item:  17.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Glenn van der Zee, Assistant Superintendent of Educational Services and ShaKenya Edison, Director of Student Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Approve Inter-District Attendance Agreement with Morgan Hill Unified School District
	 
	 
The East Side Union High School District is requesting authorization to enter into an Inter-District Attendance Agreement with Morgan Hill Unified School District, pursuant to California Education Code Section 46600 and Assembly Bill 2444.
	 
The term of this agreement shall be effective July 1, 2015, and shall terminate on June 30, 2020.  An inter-district transfer permit issued under this agreement is only valid for one year.  A student who attends another school district other than his or her district of residence pursuant to an inter-district transfer permit under this agreement shall reapply annually for a new inter-district transfer permit each year.   The requirement to reapply for an inter-district transfer permit each school year does not apply to a student who is attending and enrolled in a school district other than his or her district of residence pursuant to an inter-district transfer permit and who will be entering grades 11 or 12 in the subsequent school year.
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize entering into an Inter-District Attendance Agreement with Morgan Hill Unified School District until June 30, 2020.

Item:  21.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cari Vaeth, Associate Superintendent of Human Resources
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Receive Certificated Class Size Report – Compliance with 10/08/04 Stipulated Arbitrator’s Award
	 
	 
On October 8, 2004, the District and the East Side Teachers Association were parties to a settlement agreement under the authority of Arbitrator Barbara Bridgewater.  In Section II, #16 of the Consent Award, the District agreed to provide a report to the Board of Trustees and to the Association President regarding the degree to which each comprehensive high school met its responsibilities under Article 15 of the Collective Bargaining Agreement.  This report is based on day seventeen (17) of school, and includes for each school:
The percentage of successful student placement on the last Infinite Campus [Student Information System] master schedule run
The total number of classes over Article 15 limits not exempted by Article 15.8 limits
The total number of students with incomplete schedules
The number of students upon which staffing projections were made and the actual number students enrolled
The changes to sites' certificated FTE allocation since the first day of school
The number of students that have had class changes since the first day of school
This report contains data retrieved from the school sites, Information Technology, and Business Services.  This report is provided to keep the Board informed regarding Certificated Class Size status.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Informational purposes only
